No small amount oi criticism has been passed upon the grouping together in one department ol a legal system ol the topics which are comprised under the ius quod ad res pertinet, and which, we may truly say, would not be co-ordinated upon any other principle of classification. The most solid objection is the inclusion oi the law os Inheritance and that os obligations in the same division with that os property and other real rights. The place of the first is due to its character as one oi the modes of universal succession, among which it ranks with adrogation, bonorum addictio libertatis causa, and (in Gaius) conventio in manum, hereditatis in iure cessio, and venditio bonorum. Through this false idea os proportion the importance ol Testamentary and Intestate succession, as an independent branch oi law, is altogether obscured·: moreover, as Savigny has remarked, these modes ‘quibus res per universitatem adquiruntur’ are ex· clusively regarded as titles to rights, whereas they arc equally sources ol obligations. ¹ Accordingly, the German· jutius, in their systematic treatises on Roman law, here abendon the Roman classification, and maire Inheritance one oi their main divisione, instead os subordinating it to that between titles to res singulae, and titles to universitates.

Why obligations are ‘res’ has been already pointed out. When an obligatio is said to be a res, the active, or creditor's side ol the rela- tion is intended.
